Line 29: Line 29:
==History==
==History==
â
According to ''[[The News & Observer]]'': "The national Modern Whig Party, as it calls itself, was started in the most unlikely of locationsâthe deserts of Iraq and the mountains of Afghanistan by U.S. troops."<ref name="newsobserver.com"/> The Modern Whig Party was organized as a grassroots movement in the beginning of 2008 as a national successor to the historical [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]]. Among the national Modern Whig Party's founding members were military veterans who had served in Afghanistan and Iraq and become dissatisfied with the deep ideological divide between the Republican and Democratic parties.<ref> WTFK 107.1 FM "Viewpoints with Lockwood Phillips http://www.wtkf107.com/images/002VPWEBCAST%20%20DAILY%20HR%202.mp3</ref> Other media outlets have touted the Modern Whig Party's moderate platform and its viable appeal during a time of ideological fragmentation within the Republican and Democratic parties.<ref>http://www.easternecho.com/index.php/article/2009/12/modern_whig_partymoderates_new_ally_</ref>
+
According to ''[[The News & Observer]]'': "The national Modern Whig Party, as it calls itself, was started in the most unlikely of locationsâthe deserts of Iraq and the mountains of Afghanistan by U.S. troops."<ref name="newsobserver.com"/> The Modern Whig Party was organized as a grassroots movement in the beginning of 2008 as a national successor to the historical [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]] (the [[Florida Whig Party]] was created a year earlier with a similar goal at the state level).<ref>http://election.dos.state.fl.us/cgi-bin/ComHtml.exe?account=45020 Florida Department of State website confirming Florida Whig Party was ballot approved in 2007.</ref><ref>"Modern Whig Party has Appeal to Some Troops: No Candidates Yet, but with Moderate Stance, it's Starting to Catch On" as published in the Marine Corps Times, Army Times and Air Force Times newspapers in June 2008</ref> Among the national Modern Whig Party's founding members were military veterans who had served in Afghanistan and Iraq and become dissatisfied with the deep ideological divide between the Republican and Democratic parties.<ref> WTFK 107.1 FM "Viewpoints with Lockwood Phillips http://www.wtkf107.com/images/002VPWEBCAST%20%20DAILY%20HR%202.mp3</ref> Other media outlets have touted the Modern Whig Party's moderate platform and its viable appeal during a time of ideological fragmentation within the Republican and Democratic parties.<ref>http://www.easternecho.com/index.php/article/2009/12/modern_whig_partymoderates_new_ally_</ref>
The grassroots movement of the Whigs has a national headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.]] and an executive committee.<ref>WKOB Eyewitness News 4http://www.kob.com/article/stories/S1065236.shtml?cat=504</ref> Less than a year after its creation, the Modern Whig Party attracted over 30,000 members nationally.<ref>http://www.richmond-dailynews.com/news.php?id=2674</ref> The current chairwoman of the Modern Whig Party is Elaine Stephens.
The grassroots movement of the Whigs has a national headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.]] and an executive committee.<ref>WKOB Eyewitness News 4http://www.kob.com/article/stories/S1065236.shtml?cat=504</ref> Less than a year after its creation, the Modern Whig Party attracted over 30,000 members nationally.<ref>http://www.richmond-dailynews.com/news.php?id=2674</ref> The current chairwoman of the Modern Whig Party is Elaine Stephens.
Line 40: Line 40:
On May 19, 2009 during a national online meeting, the Modern Whig Party grassroots movement and the [[Florida Whig Party]] jointly announced the first federal "Whig" candidate for Congress since the 1850s: [[Paul C. McKain]] of [[Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballot-access.org/2009/05/22/whig-party-name-may-again-appear-on-ballots/ |title=Ballot Access News Â» Blog Archive Â» Whig Party Name May Again Appear on Ballots |publisher=Ballot-access.org |date= |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentpoliticalreport.com/2009/05/modern-whig-party-announces-its-first-candidate-for-congress/ |title=Modern Whig Party announces its first candidate for Congress |publisher=Independent Political Report |date= |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref>
On May 19, 2009 during a national online meeting, the Modern Whig Party grassroots movement and the [[Florida Whig Party]] jointly announced the first federal "Whig" candidate for Congress since the 1850s: [[Paul C. McKain]] of [[Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballot-access.org/2009/05/22/whig-party-name-may-again-appear-on-ballots/ |title=Ballot Access News Â» Blog Archive Â» Whig Party Name May Again Appear on Ballots |publisher=Ballot-access.org |date= |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentpoliticalreport.com/2009/05/modern-whig-party-announces-its-first-candidate-for-congress/ |title=Modern Whig Party announces its first candidate for Congress |publisher=Independent Political Report |date= |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref>
  +   +
On October 19, 2009 the [[Florida Whig Party]] announced two additional candidates for Congress. [[Clayton Schock]] in [[Florida's 20th congressional district]] and [[John Annarumma]] in [[Florida's 3rd congressional district]].<ref name="ballot-access.org">"Whig Party Says it will Have At Least Three U.S. House Candidates on Florida Ballot in 2010" by Richard Winger in Ballot Access News http://www.ballot-access.org/2009/10/19/whig-party-says-it-will-have-at-least-three-u-s-house-candidates-on-florida-ballot-in-2010/</ref> According to Ballot Access News, the revived Whig Party will be the first party outside of the Republican and Democratic to have three candidates on the Florida ballot for the U.S. House in any election year.<ref name="ballot-access.org"/><ref>"Two more Whigs running for Congress in Florida" by Independent Political Report http://www.independentpoliticalreport.com/2009/10/two-more-whigs-running-for-congress-in-florida/</ref>
  +   +
In November of 2009, The [[Florida Whig Party]] announced on its website that they have officially cut all ties with the Modern Whig Party."<ref name="FloridaWhig.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.floridawhig.com |title=The Florida Whig Party |publisher=FloridaWhig.com |date= |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref><ref>"Florida Whig Party" Breaks With Modern Whig Party http://whigblog.blogspot.com/2009/11/florida-whig-party-breaks-with-modern.html</ref>The Florida Whig Party Predates the Modern Whig Party and is the only state to date that has Ballot access.<ref>http://election.dos.state.fl.us/cgi-bin/ComHtml.exe?account=45020 Florida Department of State website confirming Florida Whig Party was ballot approved in 2007.</ref><ref>"Modern Whig Party has Appeal to Some Troops: No Candidates Yet, but with Moderate Stance, it's Starting to Catch On" as published in the Marine Corps Times, Army Times and Air Force Times newspapers in June 2008</ref>
On December 12-13, 2009, the Modern Whig Party held the first national leadership council meeting in Washington DC.<ref>see independent political report</ref>
On December 12-13, 2009, the Modern Whig Party held the first national leadership council meeting in Washington DC.<ref>see independent political report</ref>
Line 58: Line 62:
==Logo==
==Logo==
â
[[Image:Whig-party-logo-design.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Modern Whig Party]]
+
[[Image:Whig-party-logo-design.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Modern Whig Party and the Florida Whig Party Logo]]
For its logo, the Modern Whig Party uses an owl, the symbol of the original Whig Party. The red, white, and blue color scheme is used once again, but with different meaning. In this case, the bird is half blue (for Democrats) and half red (for Republicans) with a white line and a band of stars dividing the two colors. The party believes that the United States' future lies in meeting in the middle, thus the placement of the stars in the middle of the owl.<ref>"Top 10 USA Political Party Logos" by Logo Design Works http://www.logodesignworks.com/blog/top-10-usa-political-party-logos/</ref>
For its logo, the Modern Whig Party uses an owl, the symbol of the original Whig Party. The red, white, and blue color scheme is used once again, but with different meaning. In this case, the bird is half blue (for Democrats) and half red (for Republicans) with a white line and a band of stars dividing the two colors. The party believes that the United States' future lies in meeting in the middle, thus the placement of the stars in the middle of the owl.<ref>"Top 10 USA Political Party Logos" by Logo Design Works http://www.logodesignworks.com/blog/top-10-usa-political-party-logos/</ref>
